reviewText: Ugh, confused! Perhaps the best puzzle game I've ever seen though. Fantastic pick up if you're into that sort of thing.

I guess in a nutshell I'd say this is the lateral puzzle-solving brother of Portal's more logical puzzle-solving. Where in Portal the rules are pretty clear early on, and you have to use those rules to further yourself through the game, Antichamber continually asks what the rules actually are. Later on in the game it evolves into some slightly more logical puzzle-solving, but even then it feels like a nice blend of lateral and logical.

The visual style is very effective at what it does, even sometimes quite pretty (there's a particular 'gallery' in the game full of cool geometry and optical illusions that I love). As in Portal, a stark, simple aesthetic is used to bring attention to what's important, although in this game the use of colour is more important and also kind of trippy.

The story feels a little odd, as it is mainly relayed through wall doodles that reveal 'insights' about life that relate to how you solve or have solved a puzzle. Of all the parts of the game I'd say that's the weakest, but I don't think it really dilutes the experience, and it at least signposts your route through the world.

I've seen that some people don't enjoy that this game refuses to hold your hand, but that's precisely what I loved so much about it. Being confused by a seemingly impossible puzzle only to realise it was obvious if I just thought about it in a different way, was really entertaining and satisfying. If you enjoy lateral thinking, if you enjoy inventive puzzle games, or even if you just enjoy being challenged and surprised, I can't recommend this game enough. One of the best puzzle games ever made in my opinion.

reviewText:
So, I just beat Antichamber. I think. The fact that I'm uncertain about that already tells you a whole lot about this game. In technical terms, one would describe it best as a first-person Metroidvania puzzler; but most conventional genre descriptors are far too generic for this convention-defier. If you love puzzles that are so headache-inducingly ingenious that the preposterous becomes intuitive, or if you just like to have your gray matter tickled, I'd definitely recommend this game.

One downside I'd note, though, is that - for some people, such as myself - the game is not only figuratively, but also literally headache-inducing. I'm not sure whether it's the brightness of the visuals, the ambient sound design, or what, but I found it difficult to play this game for extended stretches of time, which is a shame because the game is quite addicting!

Oh, I should also add, the game was very kindly gifted to me; I would not say it's worth its current price tag, though how long you'll be playing it will strongly depend on your wits and your willpower to resist looking up strategy guides.

Reality-bending first person puzzler. On first play, I thought it was interesting and clever but also very frustrating. Second time I played, I found the first manipulation device and it all started to click. The puzzles are often hard but always logical within the rules that antichamber lays out (so far at least).
The introduction of new concepts is well paced. The only thing I'm not sure I like is the fact that you'll encounter plenty of puzzles that cannot be solved until you revist them later with a new manipulation tool. There are positives to that approach but I also think it leads to a lot of confusion and frustration that could easilly put someone off.

Overall, I highly recommend this. Just make sure you're willing to stick at it for a while and you'll find a great puzzle game with some very satisfying moments.

reviewText: This game is a mind bending Piece of Art. I highly recommend anyone to play this game as its possibly the best puzzle game ever made and definately one of my favourite games of all time.

An unforgettable puzzle game that continually challenges your preconceptions..about everything. With a very steep learning curve, it's definitely a smart game made for smart gamers. The minimalist soundtrack of natural sounds, from bird calls to the crackling of a fireplace, really lulled me into a sense of immersion, curiosity and peacefulness. The art style of Antichamber starkly contrasts the hyperrealism of blockbuster games like Call of Duty: environments are sparse, with deliberate use of color and contours, but very little detail. Furthermore, the few visual cues available serve as hints or teach new game mechanics, even if their meaning is ambiguous at first. What I enjoyed most about Antichamber, after reading several interviews with developer Alexander Bruce, is that the game serves as an allegory for life's vicissitudes - sometimes you're up, and other times, you're down. The cartoon plaques in each of the game's rooms are captioned with pithy quotes (e.g. failing to succeed does not mean failing to progress) that serve not only advise the player about how to solve each puzzle, but also how live more gracefully. A must-play for gamers seeking a cerebral, but rewarding challenge.
More than a first-person puzzle

Missing your target is a frequent and needless frustration.

I cannot stress this enough, do not look online for tutorials, don't let someone else guide you through this game.

As easy as it would be to have a complete stranger guide you through your life and tell you what is correct and what is not, you don't let them because life is about making mistakes and finding solutions. This game parallels that in so many regards. It guides you through a story that only you can narrate, it helps you learn and gives you direction, but not once does it allow you to take advantage an glide right through. The game offers constant challenges and forces the questioning of what you are doing. The solution rarely is clear until you have found it, and there's no fun in allowing someone else to find it for you.

AntiChamber is a downright fascinating game and a beautiful strain on the mind, I urge anyone with the patience to pick up this game and let it take you on a strange and perplexing journey

reviewText:
If Portal's sense of humor was directed at its environment instead of its narrative.

If Obsidian's developers turned their minds towards puzzles instead of point-and-click.

Your steps bend space, space bends time, time bends you. The walls expand and contract and rearrange. Your memory is irrelevant, your skills and powers of logic are tested. Your ability to learn from your mistakes is emphasized. Consistency was left behind ages ago.

Take the Manipulator. Take the boxes.


Find the right way down through the maze, to the food, then find the exit.  Push the exit button.   If the food tastes awful, don't eat it, go back and try another way.

They want the same thing that you do, really, they want a path, just like you.  You are in a maze in a maze, but which one counts?  Your maze, their maze, my maze.  Or are the mazes all the same, defined by the limits of their paths?

Existence is simple: find the food, push the button, hit the treadmill.

But sometimes it gets much harder.  Sometimes the food makes you sick, or you can hear nearby feet racing you, urging you on.  Sometimes the button only gets you landed right back in the beginning of the maze again, and the food won't satisfy.

There is only one path and that is the path that you take, but you can take more than one path.

Cross over the cell bars, find a new maze, make the maze from it's path, find the cell bars, cross over the bars, find a maze, make the maze from its path, eat the food, eat the path.

Would you like a different type of puzzle game? I find myself coming back to this one over and over again, even though I think I've found everything...I am mistaken.\n\nDeffinatly takes your brain around the block. Give it a try

reviewText:
Extremely fun puzzle game, with a very different take on the genre. I enetered this game expecting it to be akin to Portal, and while it was in some senses, they are two entirely different experiences. Portal gets you to think with...portals, and Antichamber just simply requires you to think outside the box. While it is a simple concept, some of the challenges can prove to be quite difficult.
I really cant find many problems with this game. The only thing that comes to mind is that sometimes the  game can  double up on the solution to puzzles. This is quite noticable around midway through the game, when around 2-3 of the puzzles have the same solution. That being said, the sheer uniqueness of some of the other puzzles more than make up for this.
Some may find that the game isn't extremely replayable. However, for me this wasn't too much of a problem, and I thoroughly enjoyed the game even on my second playthrough.

Overall, amazing game, an extremely unique game to the genre, and a must-buy during sales.
9/10

reviewText:
Antichamber is a weird game to review, as it stands on a league of its own. It's not trying to be a good game. On the contrary, it's actually throwing most conventions out the window, and challenging the player to see it through.

Let's say it's a first person puzzle game. If you need a comparison, Portal would be a decent choice. However, where Portal clearly gives you the mechanics and expects you to use them to solve the puzzles, Antichamber makes you dig a lot to find those mechanics and how it all fits and interacts. The game is purposely trying to bend the players' minds at every turn, and it certainly succeeds in doing exactly that!

I'm not going to do the usual review on this game. It simply wouldn't work, and would achieve nothing. So I'm going to try to convey the game's fundamental aspects, and you'll then judge for yourself if you're interested enough.


The game also has some Metroid-vania elements regarding its map. However, while those games obey real-world" rules
date: Antichamber laughs at them. The whole game is a non-Euclidian maze (meaning it doesn't obey 3D geometry rules -- when you turn back
recommended: the rooms may have changed; maybe you can go down enough that you're back where you're started; you get the idea). However

reviewText:
Set without narrative, the game is a series of puzzles designed to bend your mind.  It's filled with puzzly gimmicks, but in the way that every one seems to press forward and forward in challenging your notions of logic.  Some puzzles take hard work, some are so insanely simple that you will feel like a genius and a ♥♥♥♥♥ simultaneously, while enjoying every moment of it.

But make no mistake, the puzzles in this antichamber are *not* linear.  Once you step in, it'll be your job to make sense of it.  Good luck.

Makes my list of top 5 games of all time for its unique approach to puzzles, clever programming, lightheartedness, and TRULY enigmatic atmosphere.  Must have for puzzle lovers.

reviewText:
This game is like life. It throws you a problem and you have to solve it. It also gives you advices on how to live your life, most of them are obvious things and it just kinda reminds you.
It also teaches you a very important thing that is necessary these days in life.... thinking out of the box.

I can only recommend it, life lessons from a game 10/10.

If M.C. Escher was to design a game on acid - it would be the first 30 minutes of Antichamber. Maybe even the first hour. This game tries to mess with your brain a lot and it will most likely do exactly this. Navigating an environment in which the place behind you must not necessarily be the place that used to be in front of you when you started walking can be a bit frustrating, but sometimes you'll be too busy thinking outside the box to even notice that. Hidden in this game are a lot of secret areas with concept art and some kind of dev-log. And there's little hints" that sometimes only make sense in retrospect.
Towards the end the game gets easier but maybe that's just because you got used to it's mechanisms.

If you like brain♥♥♥♥ and confusion is a state of mind you enjoy: This game is for you.

Oh - and there's a gun."

I cannot stress this enough, do not look online for tutorials, don't let someone else guide you through this game.

As easy as it would be to have a complete stranger guide you through your life and tell you what is correct and what is not, you don't let them because life is about making mistakes and finding solutions. This game parallels that in so many regards. It guides you through a story that only you can narrate, it helps you learn and gives you direction, but not once does it allow you to take advantage an glide right through. The game offers constant challenges and forces the questioning of what you are doing. The solution rarely is clear until you have found it, and there's no fun in allowing someone else to find it for you.

AntiChamber is a downright fascinating game and a beautiful strain on the mind, I urge anyone with the patience to pick up this game and let it take you on a strange and perplexing journey

reviewText:
While I did love the 4-dimensional level design - and seriously, this is some of the best level design ever - I felt that in the second half after you get all the guns to manipulate the blocks, it turns into every other block pushing puzzle game. The last part really doesn't deliver the same quality of level design as the first part and I really loved exploring the different rooms, but once you reach the exit stretch of the game that basically becomes irrelevant.

Still, I highly enjoyed the game overall, the puzzles can be a bit of a brain twister at times, especially since a couple of times the solution, even if you've guessed it, lacks a clear definite response for the player. And it really helps that the aesthetic is so minimalist, while it is striking and at times quite beautiful to look at, it also manages to not take away the mind of the player from the puzzles.

I think however that the game could've been better by actually having a plot. As it stands you're just trying to progress through the challenges you see not unlike Portal, but the difference there is that Portal actually told a story. Not just you being some lab-rat in a cage of an insane computer, it also uses its environments to flesh out the world this is taking place with scribbling on the walls and hints to what actually happened and how the weighted companion cubes are actually coffins for previous participants and scientists, etc. and there's nothing of that sort in Antichamber.

And finally, I think $20 is a bit much to ask for this game. I get that trying to create a 3D representation of what a 4 dimensional world looks like does require some brainpower and talent to realize, but I've beaten the game in 3.5 hours which isn't much. I'm not saying that the game should've been longer, not at all, it's quite a good length although I've read that on subsequent playthroughs, the game takes less than a half hour to complete so it doesn't have replay value. I've bought it at the Humble Bundle for $0.50 and for that it's a steal, but I can't recommend it to others for the full price. If you can get it for $10 at a sale, that would be a fair price in my estimation.

reviewText: An unforgettable puzzle game that continually challenges your preconceptions..about everything. With a very steep learning curve, it's definitely a smart game made for smart gamers. The minimalist soundtrack of natural sounds, from bird calls to the crackling of a fireplace, really lulled me into a sense of immersion, curiosity and peacefulness. The art style of Antichamber starkly contrasts the hyperrealism of blockbuster games like Call of Duty: environments are sparse, with deliberate use of color and contours, but very little detail. Furthermore, the few visual cues available serve as hints or teach new game mechanics, even if their meaning is ambiguous at first. What I enjoyed most about Antichamber, after reading several interviews with developer Alexander Bruce, is that the game serves as an allegory for life's vicissitudes - sometimes you're up, and other times, you're down. The cartoon plaques in each of the game's rooms are captioned with pithy quotes (e.g. failing to succeed does not mean failing to progress) that serve not only advise the player about how to solve each puzzle, but also how live more gracefully. A must-play for gamers seeking a cerebral, but rewarding challenge.

So, I just beat Antichamber. I think. The fact that I'm uncertain about that already tells you a whole lot about this game. In technical terms, one would describe it best as a first-person Metroidvania puzzler; but most conventional genre descriptors are far too generic for this convention-defier. If you love puzzles that are so headache-inducingly ingenious that the preposterous becomes intuitive, or if you just like to have your gray matter tickled, I'd definitely recommend this game.

One downside I'd note, though, is that - for some people, such as myself - the game is not only figuratively, but also literally headache-inducing. I'm not sure whether it's the brightness of the visuals, the ambient sound design, or what, but I found it difficult to play this game for extended stretches of time, which is a shame because the game is quite addicting!

Oh, I should also add, the game was very kindly gifted to me; I would not say it's worth its current price tag, though how long you'll be playing it will strongly depend on your wits and your willpower to resist looking up strategy guides.

reviewText: This game is phenomenal. I can't stop playing it. Without any narration, player development, or any real plot, it drew me in.  It makes you think more than most games would. The game is designed in such a way that most of the time you overthink the solution to things. The game holds your hand for the first little while and teaches you the basics, but then it throws you out. The ambience is a nice touch. It isn't just the same track throughout the whole game, it's different tracks in different parts of the game. The game is mostly non-linear and will frustrate you a lot. I would compare this game to the Stanley Parable and Portal, but a lot harder.\n\nThe only thing I would like to change would have some hints as to who and where I am. Other than that, I love it.

To start, it has a FEW similarities to Portal and Portal 2 but is unique in its own way. It mostly deals with cube excursion and teaching lessons that do not alway follow the general laws of nature. The game is something that should be played by any puzzle game fan. It definitely makes you think and promotes the idea of anything is possible and just leaves you confused sometimes but that is why you are able to work at different locations of the place when you choose. It gives you a wide variety of puzzles as well as plenty of them to solve. The gameplay is solid and enjoyable, at least if you are not stuff on the same puzzle for a hour or more. The graphics are not amazing but that was openly expressed by the developers that they did not want to distract from the experience with fancy environments or graphics. Even without flashy effects and realistic atmosphere, the game still makes a fine puzzle game. I have had no trouble with any bugs or anything that break the game so it is good all around and I recommend it to puzzle video game fans mostly but still fun more most people I would say.

reviewText: You know a game is good when you actually feel happy when AND after completing it. Antichamber is a puzzle game you'll be glad you played. You're alone, in this mesmerising but minimal world and it just feels so right. There's something healing, almost therapeutic about the combination of being secluded, the visuals and sounds with Antichamber. Everything is so fluid, atmospheric kind of timeless. That's even before we get to the mind warping beautifully created physics of the game.\n\nYou never stop learning new concepts in this game, even to the very end; it's a game that keeps giving but it's never too impossible, all puzzles can be done if you're willing to read the signs and listen to the game. It's almost as if Antichamber talks to you, and the game changes with your every move. If you're looking for some calming gaming therapy, this is a perfect game.

I've always found non-Euclidean geometry facinating, and this game is basically an excercise in navigating such spaces. I loved the simplistic gameplay and minimalist soundtrack. I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys platforming and exploring.

I stopped playing only because I had some things that could not be postponed, and that was the ONLY reason. Can't wait to continue. I already have recommended it to everyone I know, and I want to see how other people try to solve these absolutely mind bending puzzles for the first time...
Antichamber felt something like Braid and Stanley Parable combined and all three games are definitely worth getting.
Outstanding and difficult. A must buy for all puzzle fans!\n\nNo real story but the gameplay and graphics are smooth and look nice.
Proof that games can be so much more than just games.\n\nDefinitely a top 10 game.
Its a hard puzzle game but damn it a good one!
This game is a mind bending Piece of Art. I highly recommend anyone to play this game as its possibly the best puzzle game ever made and definately one of my favourite games of all time.
Great game never beat it, but i rarely beat my games, its a must play if you get the chance.
A fun and unique puzzler that's a total mind-♥♥♥♥ at times.
Certainly a cool puzzle game, but with such a large and confusing map, I found myself stuck many times spending an hour or longer not making progress.
I did one playthough then never touched it again.\n\nWorth $15 (not really)

Awesome game. Was used against someone the other day when they laid claim that I was all graphics and no gameplay.\n\nThis game is all gameplay and practically no graphics. Here's hoping for a sequel/addon/dlc/mod/whatever it will be called.
